If some people are perhaps not as enthusiastic, that is understood, but all the ministers of the government will, at the very least, be giving positive assent to what is in this preamble because, as a government, we are saying to the people of Australia, `We think it ought to be supported.' Unlike the position we have taken in relation to the republic where, as an act of maturity and in recognition that there are genuinely held views amongst people within a common political philosophy, there will be a free or open vote.

I am very proud of these words. They are not perfect. They are not the only way of saying what is in our hearts on these issues—there is never one way of saying what is in our hearts about things of this kind—but they do represent an attempt to say something positive about decent, enduring Australian values. I hope all the members of the parliament will support them and, on that basis, I hope the Australian people take to themselves, in their own words and in their own way, a preamble for their Constitution for the next century. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Oppositions are treated with discourtesy as a matter of routine in the House of Representatives, and even from time to time in the Senate. We in the Labor Party are, when we are in government, as guilty of treating oppositions with both disdain and discourtesy from time to time as is any other political force in parliament. I do not therefore claim any unique status in that regard. But I have never before seen a situation when a matter as significant as an amendment to the Constitution was cowboyed through this parliament in two days flat in the way in which this has been without the opposition being given the courtesy of a time for a party meeting to consider it, without the normal notice of a week's gap between consideration for deliberation to take place on it and with an insistence that the Senate reach a conclusion on it within 24 hours of consideration by this parliament. I have never seen an opposition or a parliament, certainly in my time in politics, which is now quite lengthy—and I am not ignorant of the political history of this country—do such a thing. I cannot recollect any other occasion when a matter for constitutional change has been treated in such an extraordinary, cavalier fashion by a government seeking, with the sort of sentiment that the Prime Minister expressed, broad community support for the position he wants to adopt.

speech.para: Going through the consideration of the motives for this, there is no doubt in the minds of the opposition why the government want to have a preamble before us in this way. If they had any other motive in this regard, they would take pretty seriously their obligation to have this considered with a modicum of detail by the parliament. This is being put forward precisely so that the Prime Minister can have something to campaign on positively when essentially he has been negative on the primary issue that will be before the Australian people on 6 November. We cannot honour that motive. We cannot join him with a cheerio for that particular motive. Whatever the content of the document, we cannot join with him in cheerioing that particular motive.

We do not dispute the fact that it would be useful to have a preambular statement to the Constitution that properly reflects the sentiments of the community. We have absolutely no quarrel with that proposition. We understand too that, as the Prime Minister pointed out, the document is largely irrelevant to the Constitution. Unlike most preambles to most constitutions, we are specifically reserving this preamble to have no effect. Generally speaking, people are proud enough of their preambles to have them as defining documents for their constitutions. But the Prime Minister has been wise enough to decide in these circumstances that the preamble should have no effect as far as the Australian Constitution is concerned. Therefore, as a matter for deliberation by the Australian people, it is vastly inferior to the other proposition that they will have to consider and which will have a profound effect on the character of Australian institutions and our Constitution. Therefore, I suppose the cavalier fashion in which the Prime Minister has chosen to treat this has at least the justification of the constitutional irrelevance of the document which he has placed before us, but no other. If it is to have the sounding-board effect that the Prime Minister is talking about—that is, a document to express at this point in the century our feelings about ourselves—and have no other effect, then it would be particularly useful, I would have thought, to expand the consultation process.

I ask you to compare and contrast. We had, in dealing with the republican issue, an all-party committee which the government took seriously. We had, in the preparation of the question, a Constitutional Convention which the government took seriously. I have criticisms of the long title of the bill—the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) Bill 1999 . I have no criticism at all of the processes by which the government has handled the republican issue in the parliament, apart from, as I said, the issues on which we have moved amendments, and that is only appropriate in this place. The handling of it was exemplary. The handling of this is the lowest point in political relationships in a parliament for consideration of a constitutional matter which the government wishes to attach weight to and which the government wishes the Australian people to believe has a weight greater than it actually has in constitutional terms. What a tragedy that is that that should be so.

Really, the definition of ourselves as a people will be reflected in the extent to which we as a people are prepared to have sufficient confidence in ourselves to determine whether or not an Australian should be head of state. That will be a statement about the Australian people at this time in the century. That will be a statement about whether or not we have fully developed enough confidence in our own institutions that we are prepared to seize all elements of them and thoroughly Australianise them. That is a question which will define us as a people. That is by far and a long way the only significant thing that we will have to come to consider.

But what we have here is an opportunity, and it is an opportunity unnecessarily being missed. Let me acknowledge this: this preamble is a country mile from the humiliating and ghastly piece of work that was handed down by the Prime Minister as the product of his work, and almost his work alone, some months ago. I must say my objection to it was not that it contained the word `mateship'; my objection to it was that it was a negative defensive document representing 25 years of late 20th century Liberal Party grievances. It was the opening lines of a prime ministerial rah speech to the Lane Cove branch of the Liberal Party to get across the point of view that somehow or other the world had done them in since the days of the Vietnam War. That was what that particular statement was all about when it had things in it like this:

Australians are free to be proud of their country and heritage, free to realise themselves as individuals, and free to pursue their hopes and ideals. We value excellence as well as fairness, independence as dearly as mateship.

Australia's democratic and federal system of government exist under law to preserve and protect all Australians in an equal dignity which may never be infringed by prejudice or fashion or ideology . . .

Our dignity was never to be infringed by Carla Zampatti. Not under any circumstances was that to occur. It was an extraordinary piece of rubbish, and it was treated for the rubbish it was by the Australian people. It provided them a week or two's hilarity.

At least it did one thing. Sometimes there is a view—unjustified—out there in the general public that a person who spends their life professionally in politics might actually be able to pen something about politics, about the Constitution, better than somebody who devotes themselves to other callings. At least it had this democratising effect when it was released upon the unsuspecting public: everybody in Australia knew they could do better than us when it came to penning a preamble, and everybody in Australia did. I do not know about your offices, but my office became impossible as people sent one after another suggestion to replace the preamble that was proposed. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House resolves
(1) that consideration of the proposal be adjourned for 7 days to give Australian citizens an opportunity to consider the matter and have an input into the contents of the preamble; and
(2) that it should meet again at a special sitting on or before 20 August to enable the views of citizens to be considered before the House completes its consideration of the measure".

It is not our wish to delay this proposition, so it cannot be considered on 6 November, but there is a week available to you for that problem not to arise, and that week should be fully seized. No doubt we will have them coming up and saying to us that it is a bit expensive to call back the parliament once—too embarrassing, too difficult to call the parliament back for one day to consider a proposition to stand in the Australian Constitution for all time. I am sorry, but if you are going to amend the Constitution you can at least be prepared to contemplate the possibility of putting us all to the inconvenience and the expense of one further day's consideration of this matter so that the Australian people can be included within this. Because I am afraid you sitting down for a chat with Meg Lees is not a sufficient basis either on which to draft the Constitution.

I say about the content that it is vastly improved and has the capacity to be acceptable. You would not want to junk these words in the way in which you absolutely had to junk the words of the previous proposition before us. There is dignity in a lot of these words. There is an opportunity here for precisely the thing that the Prime Minister asked for if he is prepared to entertain a sensible process for the consideration of it. I suppose this goes not just for his consideration but also for the Democrats as well.

I would hate it to be a motive in the minds of the Democrats as they consider this to have this thing cowboyed through the Senate in 24 hours flat because they fear they will be overrun with the concerns of their supporters about the way in which they have handled several issues here. If I have a complaint with the Democrats' handling of this, it is this: if it is, as the Prime Minister states, that they went to the wall on the issue of mateship and not on the issue of a decent statement about our indigenous people—if it is true, and it may not be, that they went to the wall on that rather than on the other—they are condemned. I suspend judgment on all of the undertakings that they have been giving members of our indigenous community for a very lengthy period because I do not know the details of those internal discussions, but the haste with which they seek this issue to be put makes me suspect that the details may be as I have suggested and may become public in very short order.

I do not think the word `mateship' belongs in a constitution, but I do not have any problems with it. If it happened to be sitting in this document and the other sections of it were better, it would not worry me for a minute. So, Prime Minister, here is this: we will stick your `mateship' back in here, if that is what you want; give the Aboriginals something decent on indigenous matters. You do not need to deal with them. You name the amendment you want on mateship and we will pass it. We have the numbers here to do it. We have the numbers in the Senate to do it. We will pass whatever you want on mateship. That is our offer. Whatever you want on mateship we will pass, provided we have a recommendation that actually unites all of the Australian people—and, most importantly, the indigenous community—on that section that talks about indigenous people.

I would have thought that that is a pretty fair offer. We will cop mateship; you cop decency in the treatment of the Aboriginal people. There are no problems with that as far as we are concerned. I must say I have not followed that through with every single member of their caucus, but they are now committed. Among other things, we have not had an opportunity to call a caucus meeting on this. I know that from time to time it may not trouble our political opponents that we do not have that time, but I think it is extraordinary, when you have something like this, to rush it through.

You announced immediately before question time that this was how you intended to handle it. You invited the opposition to have a meeting on it by abandoning question time and then walked in immediately after it. As I said, there have been discourteous treatments of the opposition including many inflicted by ourselves, for which we bear a great shame, but we have never managed anything as low rent as this.

There are a number of things that need amendment in this. They go beyond just simply the question in relation to custodianship, and I think we need to think it through. Prime Minister, I do not think you should say, in what is otherwise an excellent sentence `never forgetting the sacrifices of all who defended our country and our liberty in time of war'. I think it is important that you delete the word `war' and put in the word `conflict' which has a significant meaning to Vietnam veterans, to those involved in the Malaysian emergency and, for that matter, Konfrontasi. None of those events were legally defined as war but they were undoubtedly conflicts. Other Australians have lost their lives during peacekeeping operations, which also do not qualify in terms of the word `war' but qualify in terms of the word `conflict'.

We will move an amendment in the Senate to delete the word `war' and incorporate the word `conflict' for fear that, if we fail to do so, we will offer unnecessary insult to Vietnam veterans and veterans of all of those other campaigns. Whilst I would look to other sections of the preamble, I thank our Vietnam veteran for drawing that to my attention. We will make certain that the Senate has a full opportunity to declare themselves on the subject of whether war should be substituted with the word conflict. I also believe we need to alter in the preamble the words `honouring Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, the nation's first people'. The first problem with that statement is that it automatically opens up a dispute between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as to `first people'. The Torres Strait Islanders are not the first people; the Aboriginals are the first people. So as a bare minimum `nation's first people' has to be altered to nation's first peoples.

I think it would be commonsense for you to use the expression `indigenous'—for us all to use the expression `indigenous'—as far as it applies. If you use that, your particular wording might be more in keeping. This is simply a statement of historical fact; it does not need any further argument. If you wish this to be historically accurate, it is the Aboriginal people who were here first. The Torres Strait Islanders were not, though they pre-dated us by a very considerable margin. We also have in the preamble the words `for their deep kinship with their lands'. I understand your interpretation of that basically incorporates kinship for lands that they currently occupy. A proper rendition of this would go more to the proposition that you have before you from the Reconciliation Council—your Reconciliation Council, I might say, since you restructured it—in which they say:
We value the unique status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the original owners and custodians of traditional lands and waters.

That is an expression in which the people whom you appointed to that council have placed great store. We ourselves have a preference for the original group of occupants in that reconciliation committee. We made our views clear on that at the time but you appointed others and they have come to that conclusion.

If you are seeking in this document an opportunity to encourage at this stage of the century by this process reconciliation with the original inhabitants of this land, then some amendments to those clauses along those lines would be sensible, for simple historical accuracy and, again, minimisation of offence. I think the Vietnam veterans are entitled to have any potential offence removed from their position and the Aboriginals have an entitlement to have any particular offence in histori cal terms removed from their position. I think you ought to take that a point further and make adjustments in a way that brings it into accord—you could not use exactly the same words, because they are not structured in the way in which your other words are—with your reconciliation committee.

Prime Minister, if you are prepared to contemplate things along these lines, you will have exactly what you asked for. I think what you have asked for is pure gold. Anybody who has devoted his life and career to politics would want it and you ought to avail yourself of the opportunity. Unfortunately, you do not have much time to consider it, as we do not have much time to consider it, over the next 24 hours. You can laugh and joke all you like about us having had our opportunity. We did put out our preamble and I am pleased to see that the sort of structure you have adopted conforms with the structure that we put out, and that you have come closer in the way in which you have presented your points and arguments to the document that was largely penned by my colleague Gareth Evans. I acknowledge the fact that your document now reads much more appropriately as a starting point of any constitution.

From that point of view, I accept the fact that bits and pieces of our approach have been picked up and that it is a much better document for it. If it is going to be a document that has reasonable structure, content and expression for a preamble to a Constitution, that is one thing, but if it is going to be a document to do the things that you want it to do, then it has to be a document with some changes to make sure that all folk have an opportunity to find it acceptable.

I may be being exceptionally cynical but, with the way in which reconciliation issues have been handled in this country over the past two or three years, you will pardon me for thinking that the mere fact that we might want to see amendment on that point is, from your point of view, pretty irrelevant as to whether or not you should contemplate movement away from your hard and fast position on this document. You may well like to go around and talk to your colleagues, after the point I have made in relation to the Vietnam War—give in on one thing and you immediately destroy your case for giving in on others, and therefore you ought to leave the document in relation to that as it stands. Prime Minister, it is precisely the point that we have incorporated in our second reading amendment to this particular proposition. If you are genuine about seeking bipartisan support, it is ludicrous to approach a parliamentary debate on a constitutional change like this by handing this down as some ex cathedra document and saying, `You deal with this or you do nothing else.'

You were very proud of an appointment you made some time ago of a gentleman named Gatjil Djerrkura. When you appointed him, you expressed a profound confidence in his chairmanship of ATSIC, and a profound confidence that you had in Gatjil a person with whom you could deal on these matters. Let me read what you had to say:

Seriously, I think the appointment of Mr Djerrkura is one of the more important appointments that has been made by the government. I had the opportunity today of meeting and congratulating all the new members of the ATSIC board—
and you went on to talk about Mr Dillon. You said:
I believe both men will bring very great talents and particular capacity to the work of ATSIC.

Mr Djerrkura is extremely well qualified for the job. He is a senior tribal man of the Wangurri people in the north-east of Arnhem Land. He is very aware of the importance of traditional indigenous culture and also the problems facing indigenous people in the remote areas of Australia.
That is what you said about Gatjil when you appointed him.
Here is what he said about you in response to the clause that he, like the rest of us, has just had the chance to read:
The changes negotiated between the Federal Government and the Australian Democrats have served to weaken rather than strengthen the recognition of Australia's first nations in the proposed preamble.
This is clearly a lost opportunity to acknowledge our ongoing custodianship of this country.
Once again, we miss out.
That is the considered opinion of Gatjil Djerrkura, the man whom you appointed, speaking on this occasion in his official position as the chairman of ATSIC.

You may or may not be disappointed in that reaction, but you should be disappointed. You may see in that reaction an opportunity. You may see an opportunity in the attitudes of the Aboriginal people to these particular clauses, but what you should see is a tragedy that that should be the attitude with which they approach this issue. Prime Minister, we are going to move amendments. I know you have said that this is set hard and fast, but we are not going to let the veterans down. I am certainly not going to let my colleague on the backbench down as far as that is concerned.

We will be moving amendments that will more properly reflect the gratitude—I know you attempted to properly reflect it—that we ought to have to Australians who have fought and died in areas of conflict. Irrespective of the fact that you have said that this is a hard and fast document that cannot be adjusted, we will try to adjust it. We will also try to adjust it because we do take seriously the view that you express on the preamble. Where the words are meant, we take seriously the expression of them, and they are that you seek to see this as uniting.

If it is your view that some people of European origin in this country will object to it because they do not think that the Aboriginals should be recognised at all, that is potentially a problem; I do not dispute that. It is a sad thing if folk feel that way, but in a life pretty long in politics—though not as long as yours—I have been around most parts of this country at different points of time and talked to people of most backgrounds. I have talked to people who are quite hostile to Aboriginal aspirations and to Aboriginal benefits—people who have very judgmental views about Aboriginal lives, with attitudes and enormous jealousies and anger about what they think is special treatment. But I have never met one—not one—who does not believe that the Aboriginals were the original occupants and custodians of this land. I have not met one! They might say, `They didn't do anything with it and they deserve to have it taken off them,' and, `It is a bad thing that they were here,' and `What a shame,' but I have never heard one of them say they were not here. I have never heard one of them say they did not have original custodianship of this land—not one of all the folk that I have met in that regard.

I do not think it is a very big hurdle to leap to have a more accurate historical reflection of the circumstances in which the Aboriginals find themselves. But it would be a tragedy if, to produce an outcome, nearly all the indigenous people of this country took offence to this particular phrase. There is a risk of this, and I hope it is not so; I really hope it is not so, because in the end this may be the question that gets put unless the Democrats can really get an act together and operate decently on this.

I think that it would be an opportunity missed for a genuine act of reconciliation. And it is without penalty. There are some who might argue that if you did something like that in a normal preamble for a normal constitution, you would create all sorts of potential legal challenges through aspects of administrative practice and laws that may be governing the affairs of your country, and you would want to think pretty darn carefuly before you did that. But in a no-risk preamble that has no legal meaning at all—no legal meaning whatsoever—which this unusual preamble would have, then to not do a reasonable job on this in terms of at least an opportunity for reconciliation, is a great pity; it is a really great shame.

My offer is good. Cop the amendments that we make in relation to all our veterans and the amendments that we make in relation to the Aboriginals—or some variant of them that is appropriate to you—and we will cop mateship. If that is the thing that has disappointed you most about your handling of this document, I think we can fit mateship in here somewhere: `and valuing independence and mateship as dearly as the national spirit which binds us together in both adversity and success'—that is not a bad place to put it. Okay, we could have mateship there. That is an appropriate place in which to put the expression mateship and we could all be happy. We will do that, you do something in relation to the Vietnam veterans and the Torres Strait Islanders, and we can have that wonderful document that you want, we can get it out there into the community, and we can all jointly campaign for a yes vote on it.

This will not necessarily be our view subsequently. This is a matter for the party to sit down and determine. We will be voting against this prospect in the House now, and it is a pity. We have not had the opportunity to have a party meeting on it. We will vote against it, I should say specifically, if our amendment is put down, because we think that this is an act of great discourtesy. That will not necessarily be the view that we hold when this matter is subsequently considered by the Australian people, but it is the view we hold now and it is related entirely to this process.

talk.start.para: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I speak today with pleasure in support of the Constitution Alteration (Preamble) Bill 1999. It is clear that the Constitution lacks a preamble which reflects the development of Australia into a fully independent nation with a distinctive national character.

speech.para: While there is a preamble to the act of the United Kingdom parliament which legally established our Constitution, as was mentioned by the Prime Minister, there is no preamble in the Constitution itself. The preamble to the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act is an interesting piece of history. It records the agreement of the people of the colonies of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania to unite in a federal Commonwealth. It reads as follows:

Whereas the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland, and Tasmania, humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God, have agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth under the Crown of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and under the Constitution hereby established:
And whereas it is expedient to provide for the admission into the Commonwealth of other Australasian Colonies and possessions of the Queen:

As a Western Australian I am particularly aware that the preamble to the Constitution Act contains no reference to the people of Western Australia. Western Australia is not mentioned in the existing preamble because it did not vote to join the Commonwealth until after the Constitution Act of the United Kingdom had received royal assent on 9 July 1900. By the time Queen Victoria issued a proclamation on 17 September 1900 proclaiming that the Commonwealth of Australia was to come into existence on 1 January 1901, Western Australia had joined. Western Australia therefore agreed to join before Federation occurred on 1 January 1901 but after the passage of the Constitution Act.

The existing preamble reflects the age in which it was written, both in content and in style. Now, 100 years later, it is entirely appropriate that the Australian people have the opportunity to consider a contemporary preamble and to consider the inclusion of that contemporary preamble in our own Constitution.

A preamble proposal became a prominent issue in the debates at the Constitutional Convention in February 1998. While the convention considered the issue in the context of change to a republican form of government, the two issues do not need to be linked. Change to a republic does not necessarily involve the inclusion of a new preamble. Nor should consideration of a new preamble be seen only as part of a broader change. The issue deserves consideration in its own right and has attracted enormous interest since the proposal has been raised in public debate.

The government will present the preamble question as an entirely separate and self-sufficient question at the referendum. In fact, amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 have already been passed by the parliament to enable the two questions to be presented on separate ballot papers of different colours.

The convention recommended a series of elements to be covered in a new preamble, and the form of words now proposed by the government stands well against the list. The statement `We the Australian people commit ourselves to this Constitution' embodies both the sort of introductory language as recommended by the convention and a powerful statement of the sovereignty of the Australian people. The proposed preamble includes a measured reference to God as well as recognition of our federal system of government, the rule of law and the objective of equality of opportunity for all. It also includes a sincere acknowledgment of the importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, their cultures and their relationship with the land.

The Leader of the Opposition suggested that it would be a tragedy if the provision that is included in the constitutional preamble proposed by the Prime Minister were divisive of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and of, in effect, the indigenous people and the non-indigenous people. I would simply comment that the use of language like `tragedy' is unfortunate in this context when what is sought is unity. In this context, to achieve unanimity is something really beyond hope, but to achieve substantial agreement on all fronts is, I think, a genuine prospect with the language that is used in the preamble. There are also strong references to cultural diversity and respect for the natural environment. There are references to immigration and the impact that that has had. It is perhaps worth noting that almost all of the 140 members of the House of Representatives and the 76 members of the Senate are descendants of immigrants or immigrants themselves.

The inclusion of a tribute to those who made sacrifices in times of war was not among the convention recommendations but surely must have the support of Australians. The formulation is inclusive of those who sacrificed their lives, those who put their lives at risk and those who supported them, whether overseas or in Australia. The Leader of the Opposition raises issues in relation to this of the type that could be raised in relation to almost every provision in any attempt at a preamble and highlights the fact that there will be different views on different formulations no matter how hard you try to get unanimity.

The convention was particularly concerned that care be taken to draft the preamble in such a way that it does not have implications for the interpretation of the Constitution. The Leader of the Opposition referred to this as though the provision in the Constitution Alteration (Preamble) Bill 1999 referring to the preamble not having legal force was an entirely negative quality. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that he was a delegate to the Constitutional Convention which took that view by a substantial majority. It recommended an express statement in the Constitution that the preamble not be used to interpret other provisions of the Constitution, and the government has included a carefully drafted clause in the bill. It provides that the preamble has no legal force and should not be considered in interpreting the Constitution or in fact any law in force in the Commonwealth or any part of the Commonwealth. The provision proposed is in the form of a new section 125A which reads as follows:
The preamble to this Constitution has no legal force and shall not be considered in interpreting this Constitution or the law in force in the Commonwealth or any part of the Commonwealth.

This is not intended to signal that the preamble can just be ignored. If approved at a referendum, it will be a powerful public statement of the values and aspirations of contemporary Australia. How laws should be developed to pursue those values and aspirations must however be a matter for judgment by the elected representatives of the people and the open processes of legislation. It should not be a matter for judicial determination based on the interpretation of what are necessarily broad statements and it should not be the occasion for judges to engage in the pursuit of personal agendas. That opportunity is presented if very broad statements are seen as the basis of legislation.

The development of the preamble follows an extensive public debate on the exposure draft released in March this year by the government. Nearly 700 submissions were received in response to the government's invitation for comments, and a wide debate ensued in the media on other drafts. Daily, there was more than one draft in newspapers from different sources. Given the extent of the public contribution, to contemplate that 148 members of the House of Representatives and 76 members of the Senate would not have different views on the formulation of particular words is pie in the sky. Obviously, in this particular case, individuals would draft things differently. There may well be 224 different versions of a preamble if each individual member of the Commonwealth parliament were given the responsibility. What we have is a draft which should be acceptable to almost everybody.

The proposal now before the House has taken into account the extensive public discussion that ensued and the numerous submissions that were received in response to the government's invitation and that were presented in the media. That public debate appeared to reflect a genuine desire on the part of Australians to have the opportunity to vote for a preamble which expresses the contemporary values of Australians. Passage of this bill will give the electors of Australia the opportunity to express their views.
I commend the bill to the House and I urge members to support it. I indicate that the government does not support the Leader of the Opposition's amendment.

talk.start.para: —The most interesting thing about the Prime Minister's speech is that, instead of it being a unifying and proud speech, it was made very much in the defensive. It was made very much in the context of describing a process of political negotiation and compromise. That stance, I suppose, was made necessary because of the way that this government has presented the Constitution Alteration (Preamble) Bill 1999. It goes without saying, as we all know, that any proposed amendment to any act of parliament, no matter how trivial, is first tabled with an explanatory memorandum. The public is then consulted and the opposition have the opportunity to prepare their argument.

speech.para: As the Leader of the Opposition indicated, there could be no more significant amendment to our Constitution—indeed, to the very heart and soul of our Constitution, the foundation of not only our legal system but our political system—than an amendment to the preamble. It is an absolute disgrace and an indication of absolute incompetence that that was not done. As the Leader of the Opposition indicated, it quite easily could have been done.

On 31 May, the Attorney-General referred two referendum bills—the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) Bill 1999 and the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill 1999 —to a joint select committee. Page 4,516 of Hansard will show that he specifically excluded from the terms of reference a consideration of the preamble issue. So all the work that has been done by that committee well and truly could have covered this issue. I was a member of that committee and many witnesses were chomping at the bit to have their say on the preamble and were not given that opportunity. Indeed, we were precluded from considering it.

I agree with the Leader of the Opposition that, by and large, it is a good document. It is certainly a substantial improvement on the former draft, which was best described to me by a constituent as the Leyland P76 preamble. It certainly harked back to a prior era. It had no class and effectively was a dud. But this document does have some class to it. It is misleading for the Attorney-General to say that you are not going to get a document to satisfy all Australians. What it lacks, and it stands out straightaway, is reference to custodianship. As today's media release from ATSIC which the Leader of the Opposition referred to stated:

The word custodianship has value in this context because it has become accepted amongst Indigenous people as the English word most closely approximating our deep and enduring relationship with our country.

So to impose, in a very patronising, parental sense, a preamble on indigenous Australians in a matter so crucially important to them without consulting them is, quite frankly, an insult and quite contrary to a unifying process—all the more so when you realise what the Prime Minister has been about. He has been advancing the need for a preamble for the politics of the issue. For instance, on 8 February this year, the Prime Minister said, in response to a question from the Leader of the Opposition:

Let me tell you my view on the preamble. I think that, as we approach the Centenary of Federation, there are a growing number of Australians—Liberal and Labor, republican and anti-republican alike—who would like to see embedded in the basic document of this country some recognition of the prior occupation of the landmass of Australia by the indigenous people. That is my view. As I go around Australia, I find a greater unanimity of support for that than I do on the issue of the republic.
Where is it here? With respect, it is not here at all. Again, on 24 March this year, and again in response to a question from the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister said:

The existing preamble is part of the enabling act of the British parliament to which the Australian Constitution is a schedule. The purpose of the exercise is to insert for the first time a preamble in our Constitution. There is no reference in the existing preamble within the British enabling act to the indigenous people of this country.

I think it is the desire of everybody, if there is to be a new preamble, a real preamble to our Constitution, to have an appropriate reference to the indigenous people. But, in order to have an appropriate reference, you need to have words that will gather the maximum degree of support.

Clearly he has not, and clearly no genuine effort has been made to achieve that, because indigenous Australians have not been consulted. Instead of being a document by Australians for Australians, this is a document done in the backrooms in a political deal between the government and the Democrats for politically expedient purposes. It belittles the whole process.

We are aware of the criticism that will be repeated from eminent Australians as to the absence of reference to custodianship of the land by the Aboriginal people. We are reminded of the comments of Malcolm Fraser and of former Senator Viner's comments as well. These are notable Australians from the conservative side of politics, but they are all acutely aware of the intensity with which indigenous Australians regard this issue. It is literally a tragedy—and I use that word despite the Attorney-General's objections—that indigenous Australians clearly will be so profoundly disappointed with this document for that omission. To omit that word is, quite frankly, small. It is not leadership at all. It is a small act.

The Prime Minister is entitled to appreciate that, as the leader of the nation, he does have substantial kudos attached to that office. If he picked up the ball and ran with the issue Australians would fall in behind. There is no concern at all, to be realistic, that there would be any significant objection to the inclusion of a reference to custodianship. The Prime Minister on a previous occasion has said that the reference may have some legal significance, and I assume there he is talking about the context of native title claims. The first answer in response to that is, as the Attorney-General read out, proposed section 125A of the document will prevent that having any legal significance. Not one notable Australian, eminent jurist or academic has been brought forward to say that reference to custodianship in the preamble would in any way, shape or form affect the native title debate.

I recall the Prime Minister in fact being on the record as saying that he personally had no objection to the term. If he has no objection to the term, he should pick the ball up and run with it. He will carry the day in parliament and he will carry the day with the Australian people, and it will be a document and a moment that he can be proud of. There have been numerous steps. There is no doubt at all that this document, as proposed, is not an advance on the steps that have occurred; it is a retrograde step.

As early as 1975, Senator Neville Bonner moved a motion recognising the prior Aboriginal ownership of the Australian continent. At that time, that was unanimously supported in the Senate by both sides of politics. In 1988, after significant pressure by the religious leaders of the nation, the very first act of the parliament in this House in our bicentennial year was for the Prime Minister to move a motion. The first two clauses that Prime Minister Hawke moved were:
That this House—
(1) acknowledges that:
(a) Australia was occupied by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thou sands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788;
(b) Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown;
That motion was unanimously supported in both houses of parliament, and the historical significance of that motion cannot be disregarded.
But Prime Minister Hawke's comments are very pertinent to the debate at hand. During the debate he said:

We must add one logical step and draw one conclusion of ultimate significance. We must, if we are truly to fulfil our responsibilities as the elected representatives of the Australian people, express our utmost determination to promote reconciliation within our community, and we must do it today. We must, in the words of the third part of this motion, state the desirability of the Commonwealth further promoting reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens,—
That is a profound statement of the required leadership. Indeed, he said:
It's a politician's job to recognise when the will is there to do something; but they also have a responsibility to create that will.

And there is no doubt that we all have that responsibility. Certainly the Prime Minister as a national leader has that obligation, because a preamble serves a purpose that is educative, unifying and uplifting. This is a document with which the Prime Minister could really make his mark on Australian history by showing some generosity of spirit, some leadership, and by taking forward even those who perhaps may be unwilling. They will go gently, mark my words.

Another significant marker, which we are all of course aware of, is the Constitutional Convention's recommendation of February two years ago. That unanimously resolved that the preamble should include:
Acknowledgment of the original occupancy and custodianship of Australia by Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders;
Clearly, when you have people like Bruce Ruxton, Digger James and representatives of all walks of life supporting unanimously such a proposition, to disregard it is, again, a tragedy.

Of course, as recently as 3 June of this year the Prime Minister quite appropriately moved a motion recognising the issuing of the draft declaration for reconciliation. That is, I believe, unanimously supported by both sides of parliament. It said:
We value the unique status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the original owners and custodians of traditional lands and waters.
We respect and recognise continuing customary laws, beliefs and traditions.

So there we have a significant history of this parliament unanimously expressing the reality of prior ownership of this land and, indeed, the recognition of Aboriginal custodianship of this land. Indeed, that historical fact is now a legal fact since the High Court Mabo decision of 1992. We can all recognise that in our Constitution because it is, as I have said, a legal and historical fact.

The Leader of the Opposition has offered a compromise which can easily be achieved. With good spirit and goodwill on both sides, there will be no problems in achieving a document which, as I have said, is unifying, educative and uplifting of the Australian people. The parliament, however, has left itself open to criticism and, indeed, to the potential for a genuine and successful legal challenge to the referendum to include the preamble in November.

I say that because there is significant debate as to whether section 128 of the Constitution allows an amendment to anything other than the Constitution. The preamble will not be included in the Constitution but, rather, will be included in the preamble to the Constitution, that part of the British enabling act. That is a live area for debate. I do not think there would have been a snowflake's chance in hell of that ever being raised as an issue if this document was a unifying document. But the fact is that it will not be. That such tremendous resentment has been caused leaves the result of a referendum on the preamble open to becoming a futility because of legal challenge. That is regrettable, but that could now happen because of the irresponsible, incompetent, uncaring position adopted by this government instead of a strong position of leadership unifying this nation.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, a constitutional preamble should pay respect to our past, acknowledge our achievements, define our values and provide inspiration for their preservation. The wording of the preamble before the House succeeds on all these criteria. The move for a preamble illustrates a growing national maturity. We now feel confident enough to put in writing as a precursor to our Constitution what we believe in, who we are and what we want.

speech.para: The preamble acknowledges our diversity and the high price we have had to pay to preserve our values of freedom, tolerance, individual dignity and the rule of law. It acknowledges the original inhabitants of this vast land and the important obligation we have to its preservation for future generations to enjoy. Most importantly, the dominant themes are unity and equality between all and for all Australians.

The current preamble, which has been most adequately explained by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the shadow Attorney-General, is actually a preamble to the act of the parliament of the United Kingdom. It is interesting to read and reflect on what is there as it is spelt out at the moment. It says:
An Act to constitute the Commonwealth of Australia. [9 July 1900]
(The Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900 is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom at Westminster)

Whereas the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland, and Tasmania, humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God, have agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth under the Crown of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and under the Constitution hereby established:
And whereas it is expedient to provide for the admission into the Commonwealth of other Australasian Colonies and possessions of the Queen:

Be it therefore enacted by the Queen's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:-
1. This Act may be cited as the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act .
2. The provisions of this Act referring to the Queen shall extend to Her Majesty's heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.

And so it goes on. There probably would be few Australians who would understand that this is what stands now and that it is an act, as has been stated, of the British government. I would challenge those who might have at some time argued that we do not need a preamble to be aware of what stands now because it spells out the need for us to be doing something about it. I have said to colleagues in the past that I thought there would be marching in the streets if it was widely promoted that this is what we have the chance to replace. I congratulate the Prime Minister for being a driving force for this change. For the opposition to argue that there has not been consultation and that there has not been time to deal with this adequately is really quite false because it has been on the agenda since the Constitutional Convention last year.

The preamble before the act of parliament of the United Kingdom is clearly outdated and inappropriate for modern Australia. It makes no reference to the state of Western Australia, but there are good reasons for that. At that time in 1900, Western Australia had not decided whether it wanted to be part of the Commonwealth and was just in fact a colony. It squanders the opportunity to provide definition and inspirational goals for the community.

I thank the Prime Minister again for bringing forward this preamble along with the referendum because these issues go straight to the heart of our national identity and will have an enormous impact on Australian civics. It is worth reading the preamble once again because to have listened to the debate from some of those opposite one would question whether they have seriously looked at it and what it means. It states:
With hope in God, the Commonwealth of Australia is constituted as a democracy with a federal system of Government to serve the common good.
We the Australian people commit ourselves to this Constitution:
proud that our national unity has been forged by Australians from many ancestries;
never forgetting the sacrifices of all who defended our country and our liberty in time of war;
upholding freedom, tolerance, individual dignity and the rule of law;

honouring Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, the nation's first people, for their deep kinship with their lands and for their ancient and continuing cultures which enrich the life of our country;
recognising the nation-building contribution of generations of immigrants;
mindful of our responsibility to protect our unique natural environment;
supportive of achievement as well as equality of opportunity for all;
and valuing independence as dearly as the national spirit which binds us together in both adversity and success.

The Prime Minister and the government have sought to bind people together, to bring people together. In introducing this legislation, the Prime Minister said that he is proud of these words. I say it is a preamble for the next century. I am disappointed that the opposition has chosen to find fault with this. There are times when there is opportunity for robust debate in this parliament, when there should be genuine conflict, when the community expect us to argue about policy, but there are times when the community expects us to work on things together.

As I have already said, this has been on the agenda since the Constitutional Convention last year. It has been talked about on radio. There have been long stories in the daily press. Individual political parties have put forward their preferred preamble. I have even written my own and sent it to the Attorney-General and to the Prime Minister. It was not accepted, and I accept that because I suspect that every one of us in this place would like to write our own preamble. The important thing is that we have a preamble that is fitting for all people in Australia, that proudly gives credit to our indigenous Australians and their continuing culture as first inhabitants, that pays them that respect, that mentions immigrants to this country and the part they have played in establishing it. That is particularly important for my own electorate with people coming from a number of nations around the world all doing their bit and now being proudly Australian.

It is very important that this preamble mentions the environment. I am pleased that it is there. It is a reminder to our young people of what they will inherit from our generation to care for into the future. The preamble has words that bind us, words that we can feel proud of and words that the younger generation can hold dear. In the portfolio in which I now serve and having a lot to do with young people I am constantly reminded of their need to feel connected with their community and their country, and connected with those with whom they work and grow up. I think that this preamble to our Constitution achieves all that it sets out to do.

I ask the opposition to view this differently, to recognise that they have had opportunities to have their say and join with us, so that when we go to the people on 6 November there will be those in the government who will be arguing for yes and no and there will be those in the government who will be arguing yes and yes—as I will be arguing. I say to all of us that the Prime Minister has been generous. He has been driven by a need to have a preamble and I commend him and his cabinet colleagues for that.

talk.start.para: —Above all, a preamble should be a uniting document. It should be an uplifting document. It should be one that brings the nation together. But it should also be accurate. I wish to restrict my comments to that part relating to our indigenous brothers and sisters, our first Australians. The proposed preamble is a nonsense. It is historically inaccurate. In terms of grammatical and anthropological aspects also, it is a nonsense. The proposed preamble reads `honouring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the nation's first people'. Torres Strait Islanders, as the Leader of the Opposition has already pointed out, are not the first people. It is our Aboriginal brothers and sisters. And you do not turn around and refer to them as `people'. This is in act after act. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation's draft document talks about `peoples', because they are not the same; there is diversity. They are not `a people'; they are peoples. That is not just a pedantic term. There is diversity in the indigenous community, if you look at those from the centre, those from the desert, those from Victoria, et cetera. At the very least, `people' needs to become `peoples'. There needs to be a change of wording. The Prime Minister should look at his own document, his Draft declaration for reconciliation , produced by a council mostly of his appointees. They have circulated a draft. Who was on that drafting committee? Aden Ridgeway was there as the Democrat representative at a public consultation process. It states:

speech.para: We value the unique status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the original owners and custodians of traditional lands and waters.
That covers all things. The Democrats were on that. The government's own representative Sharman Stone was on that. It is part of a consultation process.

Our document for reconciliation, our Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act, went through this parliament with unanimous support. The council has indigenous and non-indigenous representatives on it. It has representatives of the major political parties. This preamble does not have broad community support or participation. The process is flawed. It is all right for the Democrats and the government to do a sleazy, grubby deal behind closed doors when it comes to the GST, but when it comes to the preamble—an alteration to the Constitution—we should be facilitators for a people's document, a people's preamble, that is uplifting, that we can all be proud of. We do not want to politicise this. Do not turn around and label us as wreckers when we oppose it—when you cannot even get it right.

`Kinship with their lands' constitutes both a grammatical and anthropological nonsense. Individuals or groups can have kinship with one another but not with land. Indigenous responsibility for specific country might be totemic or custodial in nature or derived from—among many possibilities—responsibilities for creation songs or stories relating to land. But it cannot be seen or characterised as kinship. We are waiting for this Prime Minister to launch a ship that actually floats. Initially it was mateship. That has sunk without trace. Now it is kinship. That will sink faster than the Titanic, because it is not appropriate. Why? Because people got together, well intentioned—and this is an improvement on the original document that was launched by the Prime Minister earlier—but where were Aboriginal people? Aden Ridgeway is now the token indigenous person consulted. I love Aden. I have enormous respect for Aden. He is a wonderful representative for his people. But he does not represent the voice of all indigenous peoples.

What we need to do is take the politics out of this. My friend the member for Cowan has blown out of the water the reference in relation to our veterans in terms of `liberty in time of war', and he will speak on that. Why? Because what has happened is that this process has been flawed. It has not been inclusive. It has been an attempt by the Prime Minister in his hubris and the Democrat leader and her party in their hubris with a new balance of power to play politics. I say to the Democrats that this preamble, if it is not altered, if it is not more inclusive, particularly with respect to indigenous Australians, is doomed. And what a lost opportunity.

The government's own appointment, Gatjil Djerrkura, someone whom they appointed—and the Leader of the Opposition talked about it—cannot be seen as a Labor man. This is what he says, in relation to this:
The changes negotiated between the Federal Government and the Australian Democrats have served to weaken rather than strengthen the recognition of Australia's first nations in the proposed preamble.
This is clearly a lost opportunity to acknowledge our ongoing custodianship of this country.
Once again we miss out.

Why is this process flawed? Because certain politicians with hubris have captured it. Do not turn around and label us as wreckers. What did the Constitutional Convention—half appointed, half elected; republicans, monarchists—agree on unanimously? What did they applaud when it went through? Custodianship. They had a two-week meeting. They agreed on it. Who torpedoed it? The Prime Minister. He is the only person in the nation that I can recall who objected to that word. I can re member the RSL representative saying, `We don't want it in the preamble. Put it in the body of the Constitution where they get substantive rights.' Bruce Ruxton and his colleagues and Dame Leonie Kramer all got behind it. We are saying that this is not good enough, because we need to be above that.

I think that, with a bit more work and a bit more goodwill, there need to be amendments that we can all embrace, and then let us get on with the blue over the republic. But what I do not want is to have second best. I do not want a backroom deal that is dishonourable, that perpetuates what happened at the time of Federation. The indigenous people were not at the table then, nor were women. There was a perception of, `We know what is best for you.' I do not know what is best for Aboriginal people. They do: let them make their own mistakes.

I say to this Prime Minister that you are merely the custodian of the office of Prime Minister. You will be remembered as the Prime Minister who failed to apologise; you will be remembered as the Prime Minister who failed in relation to our indigenous Australians, if you do not pull back from this and bring in our indigenous brothers and sisters. They do not ask for much, because this is not going to be a preamble that gives rights.

What we have got is a series of pieces of legislation where there was absolute division. The ATSIC Act at the time had a preamble. It has never been altered by this government since it has been there, and it acknowledges that we are dealing with people whose descendants are now known as Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders and were `the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement', and states:
AND WHEREAS it is also the wish of the people of Australia that there be reached with Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders a real and lasting reconciliation in these matters . . .
The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act was unanimously passed by the parliament. The Native Title Act, again in its preamble, acknowledges:
The people whose descendants are now known as Aboriginal peoples—
`peoples'—
and Torres Strait Islanders were the inhabitants of Australia before European settlement.

Aboriginal people were at the table when those acts were discussed. They were not at the table in relation to this preamble. We are going to make the same mistake of, `We know what is best for you; take it or leave it,' and yet you are asking us to not be wreckers! If the cap fits, wear it.

You have come a long way, Prime Minister—I acknowledge it and I am glad that you have—but you have not quite got there. Open up your heart and start listening. Your Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is now working on a document. It is inherently different from the words you used. `Kinship' sounds like Dad and Dave or the Beverly Hillbillies. It does not relate to connection with country or land. We do not understand that. How do I know it? Because I have listened to Aboriginal people. Where are they at the table? A document like this, for our Constitution at the turn of the century, with a government that says, `We are committed in our second term to reconciliation,' has to have Aboriginal people at the table as a part of the process. Do not repeat the mistakes of the past, because they dealt savagely with indigenous Australians. They thought they were going to die and go away. They are a rich, vibrant culture: give them a place at the table.
Opposition member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As my colleague says, they are a strong culture. `Kinship' is an insult. It is not the appropriate word. Relook at it, Prime Minister. You have got the opportunity; you do not have to do a sleazy deal with the Democrats on the basis of the lowest common denominator. Let us have everyone at the table: Labor, Democrats, Liberals, National Party and indigenous people. As I said, you will find some changes to this document, and I think the member for Cowan has already blown a hole in that part relating to his area of expertise and knowledge. Then do the same for indigenous Australians. Then we will have a preamble where we are all in the same boat, and it will float; it will not sink without trace like this will.

—I rise to give my full support to the preamble and I must congratulate the Prime Minister on his excellent work in bringing this together. I see the member for Banks focusing on Aboriginals' concerns with regard to their inclusion in this preamble—or, as he suggests, their lack of inclusion. I was rather interested to hear him make a comment that the Aboriginals were the first people of Australia and not the Torres Strait Islanders. I think the Torres Strait Islanders may take exception to that, because the last time I looked at a map the Torres Strait Islands were in fact part of Australia—and, of course, the Torres Strait Islanders were part—

speech.para: Mr Melham interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They were settled in the Torres Strait. Clearly, as an expert in indigenous issues, you do not understand fundamental facts. The fact is that Torres Strait Islanders were certainly there well before European settlement into that area. Having said that, I have to say to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that this is certainly bringing our vision up into the 21st century. It is certainly, I believe, a vision or an aspiration of a greater sense of identity for Australian people and pride in who we are, where we have been, where we are going into the future and what we are at the moment. It is all recognised in here and is appropriately shown.

speech.para: Going through it, I think initially there has been some concern about the fact that we had included the word `God', and I found that absolutely amazing. I think that, given the country that we are, it is appropriate to have the inclusion of:
With hope in God, the Commonwealth of Australia is constituted as a democracy with a federal system of Government to serve the common good.

I think that is great start for it. I think it is important also to acknowledge in there the service and the sacrifice of those who have given their lives for this wonderful country. That inclusion, as an extra from the original proposal, will be very much appreciated by the veterans of our community and by the families of those who have paid the ultimate sacrifice and by those who have returned from giving to our country service that has helped to make us what we are today.

Also, the reference here to the Aboriginal people—and, of course, recognising the Torres Strait Islands people as a separate indigenous group—is very, very important. So I think the wording of that, in honouring Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, is very important to give us that difference. Of course we acknowledge historical facts, that they are in fact the first people in this country, both in the Torres Strait and in mainland Australia.

As the representative of an area that has the third or fourth largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population in this country and from talking to the communities—taking the politics out of it—I do not believe that they would have a major problem with that statement because in it we are appreciating their culture. This is a positive document not a negative document, and that is important.

We also need to acknowledge the contribution made by our immigrants. These days, with a growing awareness of and a real focus on the environment, having a statement about the environment included is very positive, and we should be proud that it has been included in this preamble. I think that generally it is an excellent document.

The member for Adelaide expressed her disappointment at the lack of support from the opposition. I suggest to the member for Adelaide that the opposition are the Democrats these days. The Labor Party have long since dealt themselves out of the debate on a whole raft of important issues in this country and, as a consequence, they are totally insignificant.

One disappointment I have is that we were not able to include the word `mateship'. That is something that is uniquely and truly Australian. It does not matter where we go in the world, everybody recognises mateship as something that is purely and uniquely Australian. Given that this is purely and uniquely an Australian document, it is a pity that we could not be allowed to include the one word that gives us that real sense of identity as Austral ians. Nevertheless, I am certainly proud to give my full support to this preamble.

talk.start.para: —The concluding remarks of the previous speaker, the member for Leichhardt, really do not do this debate much justice at all. This is a debate that ought to be above politics, that ought to come from the heart of those people who come into this chamber and that ought to come from the heart of those people who represent the great Australians who collectively make this nation.

speech.para: I want to urge the Prime Minister to defer this debate and I want to urge the government to support the second reading amendment. Out of respect for the people of Australia, we do need to give ourselves a week so that we can go back to our electorates and give people who feel strongly that they want our preamble to be able to stand up for the next 100 years and proudly reflect what we are about as a nation to have an opportunity to comment on it. If we force this bill through today in the time frame that the government has set down, then we will certainly not be doing justice to the debate, to the preamble or to the people that we represent.

The Attorney-General is right to say that it would be pie in the sky for anyone to think that the 150-odd members of this chamber could collectively write a preamble. It is equally pie in the sky to say that one person—namely, the Prime Minister—could capture the things that importantly make up any preamble. How can one man reflect the character, the diversity, the suffering, the triumph, the tragedy, the humour, the courage and the sacrifice of the people who make up this nation? How can one man possibly capture all of those characteristics, particularly—and I do not mean this unkindly—a person who has spent so many years in parliament so often away from the mainstream experiences of people in our nation? It is simply not fair, nor is it dinkum, for him to endeavour to confiscate from the people of Australia the opportunity to have a reasonable say and a reasonable input into what should be our preamble. Equally, it is wrong for the Prime Minister to confiscate from this parlia ment the opportunity to adequately and fully debate this preamble.

I think we have this preamble wrong in a few areas. All of the previous speakers from this side of the House have indicated that, in our view, we have it wrong in relation to our indigenous people. How can we possibly impose on our indigenous people a section in the preamble without talking to them? Indeed, how can we impose it on them in any sense? Surely the indigenous people themselves of this nation should have an opportunity to write their own section into our preamble.

As has been said before, this preamble ought to be about bringing people together. It is not going to work that way if we push this legislation through in the way that has been moved today. It will become a divisive document that will do nothing to unite and to pull Australian people together at a time when we should be doing just that—a time when we should be celebrating 100 years of nationhood.

The other area where quite clearly we have it wrong is the reference to veterans. I congratulate the Prime Minister for putting that in. As a veteran, I was pleased when I saw that reference. But, as a Vietnam veteran, let me tell the House that I was absolutely horrified when I saw the wording of the section that I am referring to, which reads:
. . . never forgetting the sacrifices of all who defended our country and our liberty in time of war . . .

Many Vietnam veterans, when they came home from Vietnam, were told that they did not take part in a real war. They were turned away from RSLs and they were shunned by many people in this nation—shunned, ostracised and turned out in the cold. I know how Vietnam veterans will feel on this issue. It is not just Vietnam veterans, however. What about those who served in Borneo, Malaya, Indonesia and in those other areas of conflict where war was never declared?

Twenty minutes would not be enough time to talk about something that I feel very strongly about and, in order to give my colleagues as much chance as they can to have a say, I do not intend to say any more. I will conclude, however, by again urging the Prime Minister to consider the amendment that has been moved by Kim Beazley. I want to thank Kim Beazley for making that point earlier on today about Vietnam veterans. I urge the Prime Minister to consider this amendment and, in fairness to all Australians, support the amendment.

talk.start.para: —Every so often in life we do get the opportunity to stand up and be statesmanlike, to espouse principle, to rise above the hurly-burly of politics, to stand up with the Australian people and to deliver what the Australian people would like us as politicians to deliver. We all know that politicians are seen as being people who will oppose what the other side of politics suggests, no matter how good that proposal is. We are expected to be confrontationalist, we are expected to be self-serving and we are expected to be small-minded and petty.

speech.para: When the Prime Minister came into the House and announced the Constitution Alteration (Preamble) Bill 1999 and what the government was seeking to achieve, I have to say that I had a great sense of pride to be part of a government that, as we approach the centenary of our Federation, is prepared to stand up and define where we are as we reach the threshold of the next millennium. The Prime Minister initially talked about a preamble in March this year. There was widespread discussion in the Australian community. There was much comment. The Prime Minister has taken on board all of the feedback. He has come into the chamber and he has brought forward this noble document, this preamble of which all Australians can be proud—and, I must say, a document which I would have expected would have gained the support of the opposition. It is a pity that the Leader of the Opposition has chosen to play partisan politics. It is more than a pity; it is a tragedy that Labor speaker after Labor speaker participating in this debate is seeking to impugn the motives of the government and the Prime Minister. They are seeking to politicise this attempt by this government to espouse where we stand as a nation.

When we look at the preamble itself it refers to `hope in God'. The Commonwealth of Australia is constituted as a democracy with a federal system of government. And then, without actually reading the preamble, it includes many things. It refers to the fact that we share many ancestries, that people have made sacrifices in time of war to make sure that the country is what it is. It refers to the freedom, the tolerance, the individual liberty and the rule of law. It refers, most importantly, to our indigenous Australians in a very statesmanlike and elegant form of words. It refers to the migrants, those people who have come from the four corners of the world to join us as Australians. And it also highlights the fact that we must take into account the importance of our environment. It talks about the support of achievement and the equality of opportunity. It stresses independence as dearly as we value the national spirit which binds us together. This document is a defining document, which will I believe gain the support of Australians throughout the country in the referendum on 6 November. I am someone who opposes Australia becoming a republic because I think we have a system of government which has served our nation well; a system of government which contributes to the freedom, stability and way of life that we enjoy. But I am very supportive of this preamble and I do intend to vote yes on 6 November because I want to be part of a government, a parliament, which is prepared to make a statement as to our national aspirations, our national position.

It is not too late for the Labor Party to join us. It is not too late for them to rise above the petty, cheap, nasty partisan politics that we have heard uttered by the member for Banks and other Labor speakers. I am immensely sad that I am standing in the federal parliament today, having listened to the contribution of those opposite. The member for Banks said that a preamble should be uplifting—a document of which we can all be proud. This is such an uplifting document. The member for Barton said that the Prime Minister should display generosity of spirit and leadership. Even the Leader of the Opposition said that the form of this preamble takes on board some of the criticism which was advanced following the release in March. In fact, he even suggested that the form of wording was very close to the wording of the member for Holt. The Prime Minister has shown enormous generosity. Members opposite have participated with disgraceful contributions. The member for Banks referred to backroom deals with the Democrats—sleazy deals. He claimed that the Prime Minister has failed. The people of Australia will, I believe, reject that rhetoric. They know that rhetoric is wrong. They know that it is despicable.

In the remaining time that I have I want to plead for bipartisanship. I want to ask the opposition to rise above the partisan morass of politics in this country. I want them to join with us, hand in hand, as we march to the next century with an important statement of where we stand as a nation. The Prime Minister is a statesman; I ask the Leader of the Opposition to also become a statesman.

talk.start.para: —I support the proposed amendments to the Constitution Alteration (Preamble) Bill. Today is a very sad day for all Australians, for the Prime Minister is attempting to ram through this legislation and not provide proper opportunity for a debate on his latest version of the preamble. The Prime Minister would be well advised to take up the invitation of my leader, the Hon. Kim Beazley, and allow this parliament a further day's sitting to consider this very, very important issue.

speech.para: I thought the preamble was meant to be inclusive—that is, for all Australians. Clearly, the Prime Minister's latest preamble does nothing to give any confidence to our indigenous brothers and sisters in the promotion of reconciliation. Even the Chairman of ATSIC, Gatjil Djerrkura—the Prime Minister's own appointment—has lost faith with the federal government. His press release just released this afternoon is titled `Proposed preamble a profound disappointment'. The Chairman of ATSIC concludes his press release:
I'd be very surprised if many Indigenous people share the view that this new draft preamble promotes reconciliation or in any way advances their aspirations.
I am disappointed on a personal level having made all political parties aware of our position and I will be interested to hear the rationale for this proposed preamble.
Indeed, all Australians will want to know the rationale for the Prime Minister's proposed preamble.
